docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: PART 32 EVIDENCE AND PROCEDURE (NEW ZEALAND) ACT 1994 (COMMONWEALTH) [rr 32.1–32.7]

heading.title: PART 32 EVIDENCE AND PROCEDURE (NEW ZEALAND) ACT 1994 (COMMONWEALTH) [rr 32.1–32.7]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 32 EVIDENCE AND PROCEDURE (NEW ZEALAND) ACT 1994 (COMMONWEALTH) [rr 32.1–32.7]

entry.emph: Service in New Zealand of and failure to comply with subpoenas — Rules 32.1–32.4

row.entry: These rules govern the procedure for service of subpoenas in New Zealand under the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 (Commonwealth) including their form requirements. The rules also permit a person to apply to the court for a certificate confirming failure to comply with such subpoenas.
This rule governs the procedure for the setting aside of subpoenas under the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 (Commonwealth).

These rules provide for giving evidence by video-link or telephone (see also rr 24.3 and 31.3) from New Zealand and set out the procedure for giving such evidence. The rules also permit fax copies to be adduced in evidence in prescribed circumstances.
This Part does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division and the Industrial Relations Commission (when constituted otherwise than as the Industrial Court): see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
The Part is based on the former SCR Part 36A.
Leave to serve application for subpoena ‥ [r 32.2]
Production of document or thing pursuant to subpoena ‥ [r 32.3]

p.text: In this Part:
means an inferior court.
means the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 of the Commonwealth.
Expressions used in this Part have the same meanings as they have in the Commonwealth Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 32.2] r 32.2 Leave to serve subpoena (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Leave to serve subpoena (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 3)

p.text: Application for leave under the Commonwealth Act to serve a subpoena in New Zealand must be made:
if the subpoena is issued in proceedings in the Supreme Court, by motion in the proceedings, or
in any other case, by summons in the Common Law Division joining as defendant the person to whom the subpoena is addressed.
The application must be supported by an affidavit annexing a copy of the subpoena and setting out the following:
the name, designation or occupation, and address of the person named and whether that person is over 18 years of age,
the nature and significance of the evidence to be required from the person named, or of the document or thing required to be produced by that person,

details of the steps taken to ascertain whether the evidence, document or thing could be obtained by other means without significantly greater expense, and with less inconvenience, to the person named,
the date by which it is intended to serve the subpoena,
details of:
the calculation of the sum sufficient to meet reasonable expenses in complying with the subpoena, and
how and when those expenses are to be paid, or tendered, to that person in money or in vouchers,
if the subpoena requires the person named to give evidence, an estimate of the time that person will be required to attend to give evidence,
details of any facts or matters known to the deponent which may provide cause for the subpoena to be set aside under section 14(2) and (3) of the Commonwealth Act.
Unless the Supreme Court orders otherwise, the applicant for leave may proceed without serving the summons or notice of motion on any person.

Before granting leave under the Commonwealth Act to serve a subpoena, the Supreme Court may require the applicant for leave to undertake to meet the expenses or loss reasonably incurred by the person named, not being a party to the proceedings, in complying with the subpoena, if those expenses or loss exceed the allowances and travelling expenses to be provided to that person at the time of service of the subpoena.

For proceedings in the Supreme Court application may be made under the Commonwealth Act for leave to serve a subpoena pursuant to s 9(1) or in the case of proceedings in the District Court pursuant to s 9(2). In both cases, leave for service must be sought from a Supreme Court judge. While the application must be made formally, by motion or summons (see r 32.2(1)), there is no requirement to serve the form of application before proceedings: see r 32.2(3). At least in relation to proceedings in an “inferior court”, it has been held that the jurisdiction of the court (relevantly Supreme or Federal) to exercise the power conferred by s 9 (specifically subs (2), (3) and (4)) of the Commonwealth Act to issue a subpoena in New Zealand, may only be enlivened once a subpoena has in fact been first issued by the inferior court for which the documentation is required by the moving party. This draws a distinction between issue of a subpoena and its service or enforceability: Ualesi v Expeditors International Pty Ltd [2004] FCA 1705, BC200408965 Conti J, 20 December 2004, at [22]–[26] (this aspect of the proceedings relevantly considered the power of the Local Court to issue subpoenas to recipients in New Zealand).

Section 9(3) of the Commonwealth Act deals in a non-exclusive way with the matters that the judge to whom an application for leave to serve is to take into account. One issue is whether the evidence or documents could be obtained by other means without significantly greater expense, and with less inconvenience to the person named. That requirement will usually be satisfied where there is evidence that the documents in question relate to a transaction in which party subpoenaed played an advisory or other professional role for or in relation to one of the parties and there is no other apparent source from which the documents may be obtained. The affidavit requirement in r 32.2(2)(a) in part, reflects the provisions of s 9(5) of the Commonwealth Act, to the effect that the judge must not give leave if the person named in the subpoena is less than 18 years old. It has been held that s 9(5) does not imply any requirement that the judge should actively inquire into the age of the person to be served. Thus, there is no specific need to inquire if either there is no evidence as to the person's age or such evidence as there is does not show the person to be under 18 : Khatz Capital v Wilding [2003] NSWSC 173 per Barrett J, 27 February 2003, BC200300995 (on the facts the age issue was not of real concern as there was some hearsay evidence and the judge was willing to infer that none of the recipients (the partners of PriceWaterhouseCoopers, New Zealand) named in the subpoena were under the age of 18). The absence of evidence as to the applicant’s willingness or capacity to meet any such expenses and as to the precise relevance of the documents sought by the applicants to any issue arising in the proceedings will generally be fatal to an application: Ualesi v Expeditors International Pty Ltd [2004] FCA 1705 , (Conti J, 20 December 2004, at [15], [22], [26] (the application failed for other reasons as well).
Legislation cited in [32.2.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 s 15(1), s 9.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 33.11.

The statutory entitlement ( s 15(1) of the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 (Cth)) may give rise to a debt that is enforceable in separate proceedings. An issuing court may also order payment of the person’s compliance expenses: see s 15(4) of the Act. In ordering compensation the issuing court does so in accordance with its own rules, supplemented by the matters referred to in s 9 of the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 (Cth). The relevant authority for the awarding of expenses in NSW courts is UCPR r 33.11 : see Re Dovico; Ex parte Mayne Wetherall (2012) 265 FLR 445; [2012] NSWSC 822; BC201205333 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 32.3] r 32.3 Production of document or thing under subpoena (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Production of document or thing under subpoena (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 4)

p.text: If the court receives a fax under section 17 of the Evidence Amendment Act 1994 of New Zealand, the registrar may confirm with the registry that issued the receipt in New Zealand that the document or thing produced is able to be transported to the Supreme Court as soon as practicable so that the document or thing may be produced in the Supreme Court on the date the person named in the subpoena was to have attended.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 32.4] r 32.4 Failure to comply with subpoena issued by the Supreme Court (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Failure to comply with subpoena issued by the Supreme Court (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 5)

p.text: A person may apply to the Supreme Court for a certificate under section 16 of the Commonwealth Act by filing a notice of motion together with:
an affidavit of service of the subpoena and order and notice referred to in section 10(3) of the Commonwealth Act, and
an affidavit stating:
particulars of the order granting leave to serve the subpoena, and
whether application was made to set aside the subpoena and, if so, particulars of the application and of its outcome, and
that the subpoena was not complied with, and
a draft certificate.
Despite subrule (1), application for a certificate may be made orally if the proceedings in which the certificate is sought are then before the Supreme Court.
Unless the Supreme Court orders otherwise, the applicant need not serve notice of motion for the issue of the certificate.
An application under subrule (1) may be determined or dealt with by the Supreme Court in the absence of the public and without any attendance by or on behalf of any person.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 32.5] r 32.5 Setting aside subpoena (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Setting aside subpoena (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 6)

p.text: A person may apply to the Supreme Court to set aside a subpoena under section 13 of the Commonwealth Act by filing a notice of motion together with an affidavit setting out the facts and grounds on which the application is based.
The notice of motion must be filed at, or faxed for filing to, the Sydney registry of the Supreme Court.

If the Supreme Court receives a notice of motion by post or fax, it must acknowledge receipt and advise the applicant whether or not the notice of motion has been accepted for filing and, if it has not been accepted, the reasons for its rejection.
The registrar must serve the notice of motion and affidavit on the party who obtained leave to serve the subpoena, and may do so by faxing them to that party's fax number.
An application under this rule is to be determined in such manner as the Supreme Court may direct.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 32.6] r 32.6 Evidence by video-link or telephone (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Evidence by video-link or telephone (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 7)

p.text: A person may apply to the Supreme Court for a direction under section 25 of the Commonwealth Act (being a direction that evidence be taken, or submissions made, by video-link or telephone from New Zealand) by filing a notice of motion together with an affidavit stating the following:
the reasons why such a procedure is desirable,
the nature of the evidence to be taken,
the number of witnesses to be examined,
the expected duration of the evidence,
whether issues of character are likely to be raised,
in the case of submissions, the expected duration of the submissions,
the facilities available for such a procedure or that can reasonably be made available,
that the requirements of section 26 or 27 of the Commonwealth Act are able to be met.

In deciding whether to grant the application, the Supreme Court may take account of the matters set out in the applicant’s affidavit in addition to any other matters considered to be material, including cost and convenience to the witness and all parties.

If the Supreme Court makes a direction under section 25(1) of the Commonwealth Act that evidence be taken, or submissions made, by video-link or telephone from New Zealand, it may direct the registrar to arrange and co-ordinate the appropriate facilities in Australia and New Zealand.
Without limiting the generality of subrule (3), the Supreme Court may direct:
that the registrar arrange for the evidence to be given, or the submissions to be made, at the High Court of New Zealand or at another place approved by that court, and

that an officer of the High Court of New Zealand, or another person approved by the Supreme Court, be requested to be present to assist in the transmission of the evidence or submissions and, in particular, to:
introduce witnesses to be called and legal representatives, and
assist with the administration of oaths, if necessary, and
assist with the implementation of any directions or requests given or made by the judicial officer or other officer hearing the evidence or submissions.

Related powers relevant to applications for the taking of evidence by video link and the considerations on such application are set out in rr 24.3 and 31.3 and the notes thereto. Generally, legislation dealing with video link evidence is generally to be read beneficially: Bell Group Ltd (in liq) v Westpac Banking Corp (2004) 208 ALR 491; [2004] WASC 162; BC200404721 , Owen J at [37], approving Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2004) 49 ACSR 578; [2004] NSWSC 467; BC200403134 at [43]. Owen J at [169] adopted Austin J’s statement of basic pprinciples which inform the current approach to video-link applications. Each case must be assessed on its merits and according to its own peculiar circumstances. Factors such as the degree of centrality that the evidence bears to the issues in the case, the likely length of the cross-examination and whether there is likely to be significant reliance on documents must all be considered: Owen J at [171].

In light of some emerging divergence on the law of Australia and New Zealand as to immunity of participants in the hearing, (see D'Orta-Ekenaike v Victoria Legal Aid (2005) 214 ALR 92; [2005] HCA 12; BC200500919 ; cf Lai v Chamberlains NZ Court of Appeal, unreported 8 March 2005 CA17-03), the impact of this on the giving and receiving of evidence by video link may need to be considered: Bell Group Ltd (in liq) v Westpac Banking Corp (2004) 208 ALR 491; [2004] WASC 162; BC200404721 at [77]–[123] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 32.7] r 32.7 Fax copies (cf SCR Part 36A, rule 8)

p.text: Part 6 of the Commonwealth Act is taken to apply to a fax of a document in the same way as it applies to the original of the document (whether or not that original is itself a copy or an extract of a document).
If a fax of a document is adduced in evidence under Part 6 of the Commonwealth Act, the party adducing that evidence must file in the registry a copy of the fax.
